Layer.Name: grav_jgmro_120d_anomerr_095
Layer.Title: Mars Gravity Anomaly Uncertainty 120d (deg. 95, JPL)
Layer.Abstract: This file contains a digital map of the Mars gravity anomaly formal uncertainty derived from the covaraince matrix for the spherical harmonic coefficients of the JPL MRO120D Mars gravity field. Each point gives the Mars gravity anomaly error in milligals, which is the error of the model gravity on the geoid defined by the reference ellipsoid with semi-major-axis = 3397.0 km, GM = 42828.37582 km**3/s**2, flattening = 5.079304192e-3, and rotation rate = 7.088218081e-5 rad/s. The JGMRO_120D_ANOMERR_095 gravity anomaly is computed from a truncated MRO120D solution (from degree 2 up to degree 95). Source data: jgmro_120d_anomerr_095.lbl, jgmro_120d_anomerr_095.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_jgmro_120d_anom_095
Layer.Title: Mars Gravity Anomaly 120d (degree 95, JPL)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the gravity anomaly derived from the JPL MRO120D model of the Mars gravity field. Each point gives the Mars gravity anomaly in milligals, which is the difference of the model gravity on the geoid from the normal gravity on a reference ellipsoid with semi-major-axis = 3397.0 km, GM = 42828.37582 km**3/s**2, flattening = 5.079304192e-3, and rotation rate = 7.088218081e-5 rad/s. The JGMRO_120D_ANOM_095 gravity anomaly is computed from a truncated MRO120D solution (from degree 2 up to degree 95). Source data: jgmro_120d_anom_095.lbl, jgmro_120d_anom_095.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_ggmro_120_geoiderr_90
Layer.Title: Mars Geoid Uncertainty (degree 90, GSFC)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the Mars geoid heights formal uncertainty derived from the error covariance of the spherical harmonic coefficients of the NASA GMM-3 gravity field. Each point gives the Mars geoid height error in m, which is the geoid error on the grid defined from -89 S to 90 N and 0 E to 359 deg E. The map is produced by Antonio Genova as a postdoctoral scientist at NASA GSFC under the auspices of the MRO Gravity Science Team, and under the direction of M.T. Zuber and F.G. Lemoine. Source data: ggmro_120_geoiderr_90.lbl, ggmro_120_geoiderr_90.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_ggmro_120_geoid_90
Layer.Title: Mars Geoid (degree 90, GSFC)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the Mars geoid heights derived from spherical harmonic coefficients of the NASA GMM-3 gravity field. Each point gives the Mars geoid height in m, which is computed with respect to the reference ellipsoid with semi-major-axis = 3396.0 km, GM = 0.4282837285418775E+05 km**3/s**2, 1/flattening = 196.877360, and rotation rate = 7.088218066303858D-05 rad/s. The GMM3_120_GEOID_90 gravity anomaly map is computed from a truncated GMM-3 solution (from degree 3 up to degree 90). Source data: ggmro_120_geoid_90.lbl, ggmro_120_geoid_90.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_ggmro_120_degreestrength
Layer.Title: Mars Gravity Degree-Strength (GSFC)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the local resolution on a global scale for the NASA GMM-3 gravity field. We adopted the degree-strength approach that is based on the comparison between the expected gravity accelerations, approximately 8.5 x 10**-5/l**2, and the localized uncertainties computed at each degree. Each point gives the degree of the GMM-3 gravity field at which the expected value and the error intersect. This degree represents the maximum resolution at that location on the globe. The map is in simple cylindrical projection at a resolution of 4 pixels per degree. Source data: ggmro_120_degreestrength.lbl, ggmro_120_degreestrength.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_ggmro_120_crust
Layer.Title: Mars Crustal Thickness (GSFC)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the Mars crustal thickness computed by using the NASA GMM-3 gravity model and the MOLA topography. Each point gives the Mars crustal thickness in km. We adopted a bulk density of 2900 kg/m**3 for the crust and a density of 3500 kg/m**3 for the mantle. We performed a non-linear inversion for relief on the crust-mantle boundary, applying a smoothness constraint to suppress spurious relief that reduces the amplitude by 0.5 at degree 80 and 0.25 at degree 100. The map is in simple cylindrical projection at a resolution of 16 pixels per degree. Source data: ggmro_120_crust.lbl, ggmro_120_crust.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_ggmro_120_bouguer_90
Layer.Title: Mars Bouguer Gravity Anomaly (degree 90, GSFC)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the Bouguer gravity anomalies derived by subtracting the gravitational attraction of surface topography from the free-air NASA GMM-3 gravity field. Each point gives Bouguer gravity anomaly in milligals, We adopted for Bouguer reduction a bulk density of 2900 kg/m**3 for the crust. The GMM3_120_BOUGUER Bouguer gravity anomaly map is computed from a truncated GMM-3 solution (from degree 2 up to degree 90). Source data: ggmro_120_bouguer_90.lbl, ggmro_120_bouguer_90.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: grav_ggmro_120_anomdegreestrength
Layer.Title: Mars Gravity Anomaly Strength(degree 100, GSFC)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains a digital representation of the Mars gravity anomalies derived from spherical harmonic coefficients of the NASA GMM-3 gravity field expanded only up to the local degree strength at each location. Each point gives the Mars gravity anomaly in milligals, which is the anomaly of the model gravity defined with respect to the reference ellipsoid with semi-major-axis = 3396.0 km, GM = 0.4282837285418775E+05 km**3/s**2, 1/flattening = 196.877360, and rotation rate = 7.088218066303858D-05 rad/s. This map is in simple cylindrical projection at a resolution of 4 pixels per degree. Source data: ggmro_120_anomdegreestrength.lbl, ggmro_120_anomdegreestrength.img Date of ASU ingest: 11/18/24

Layer.Name: crism_co2_frost_probability_ls_90-100
Layer.Title: CRISM CO2 Frost Prob. Ls 090-100
Layer.Abstract: This map includes an estimate of seasonal CO2 frost likelihood (expressed as a probability from 0-1 that CO2 frost is present somewhere within the spatiotemporal pixels) for regions spanning the edge of the seasonal frost caps and into the mid-latitudes between Ls range [90-100]. It relies on daytime (~3pm) mapping data acquired by CRISM, analyzed by the CRISM team to identify CO2 ice spectral markers, and represents the average frost likelihood for the specified Ls-bin. This map is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. The CRISM methodology is described in Seelos et al., 2024, The CRISM investigation in Mars orbit: Overview, history, and delivered data products Icarus, 419, 115612, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.icarus.2023.115612. Date of ASU ingest: 03/28/2025

Layer.Name: crism_co2_frost_probability_ls_50-60
Layer.Title: CRISM CO2 Frost Prob. Ls 050-060
Layer.Abstract: This map includes an estimate of seasonal CO2 frost likelihood (expressed as a probability from 0-1 that CO2 frost is present somewhere within the spatiotemporal pixels) for regions spanning the edge of the seasonal frost caps and into the mid-latitudes between Ls range [50-60]. It relies on daytime (~3pm) mapping data acquired by CRISM, analyzed by the CRISM team to identify CO2 ice spectral markers, and represents the average frost likelihood for the specified Ls-bin. This map is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. Layer.Title: CRISM CO2 Frost Prob. Ls 010-020
Layer.Abstract: This map includes an estimate of seasonal CO2 frost likelihood (expressed as a probability from 0-1 that CO2 frost is present somewhere within the spatiotemporal pixels) for regions spanning the edge of the seasonal frost caps and into the mid-latitudes between Ls range [10-20]. It relies on daytime (~3pm) mapping data acquired by CRISM, analyzed by the CRISM team to identify CO2 ice spectral markers, and represents the average frost likelihood for the specified Ls-bin. This map is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. The CRISM methodology is described in Seelos et al., 2024, The CRISM investigation in Mars orbit: Overview, history, and delivered data products Icarus, 419, 115612, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.icarus.2023.115612. Date of ASU ingest: 03/28/2025

Layer.Name: thermal_co2_frost_probability_ls_90-100_v2
Layer.Title: Thermal CO2 Frost Prob Ls 090-100 (Seasonal Frost)
Layer.Abstract: This map includes an estimate of seasonal CO2 frost likelihood (expressed as a probability from 0-1 that CO2 frost is present somewhere within the spatiotemporal pixels) for regions spanning the edge of the seasonal frost caps and into the mid-latitudes between Ls range [90-100]. It relies on an interpolated temperature map based on daytime (~3pm) surface brightness temperature data acquired by MCS from Mars years 29-35 and by THEMIS during Mars years 29-31 (i.e., with similar overflight time as MRO), and represents the average frost likelihood for the specified Ls-bin given temperature proximity to the CO2 frost point. Source data were obtained from the PDS. It is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. Date of ASU ingest: 11/07/2024

Layer.Name: thermal_co2_frost_probability_ls_150-160_v2
Layer.Title: Thermal CO2 Frost Prob Ls 150-160 (Seasonal Frost)
Layer.Abstract: This map includes an estimate of seasonal CO2 frost likelihood (expressed as a probability from 0-1 that CO2 frost is present somewhere within the spatiotemporal pixels) for regions spanning the edge of the seasonal frost caps and into the mid-latitudes between Ls range [150-160]. It relies on an interpolated temperature map based on daytime (~3pm) surface brightness temperature data acquired by MCS from Mars years 29-35 and by THEMIS during Mars years 29-31 (i.e., with similar overflight time as MRO), and represents the average frost likelihood for the specified Ls-bin given temperature proximity to the CO2 frost point. Source data were obtained from the PDS. It is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. Date of ASU ingest: 11/07/2024

Layer.Name: hirise_frost_probability_ls_90-100_v2
Layer.Title: HiRISE Frost Prob. Ls 090-100 (Seasonal frost)
Layer.Abstract: This map includes an estimate of seasonal frost likelihood (expressed as a probability from 0-1 that frost is present within the spatiotemporal pixels) for regions spanning the edge of the seasonal frostcaps and into the mid-latitudes between Ls range [90-100]. It relies on daytime (~3pm) data acquired by the specified instrument and represents the average frost likelihood across Mars years 29-35. Note that CO2 and/or water frost may be present in a frost detection. Source data were obtained from the PDS. It is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. Date of ASU ingest: 11/07/2024

Note that CO2 and/or water frost may be present in a frost detection. Source data were obtained from the PDS. It is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. Date of ASU ingest: 11/07/2024

It relies on daytime (~3pm) data acquired by the specified instrument and represents the average frost likelihood across Mars years 29-35. Note that CO2 and/or water frost may be present in a frost detection. Source data were obtained from the PDS. It is one of several frost likelihood maps generated based on Thermal (MCS/THEMIS), Spectral (CRISM), and Visible (HiRISE, CTX) data. Date of ASU ingest: 11/07/2024

Layer.Name: tes_surf_emiss_conv_themis_band9
Layer.Title: TES-derived Emissivity (Convolved THEMIS Band 9)
Layer.Abstract: These maps are described in Pankine et al. (submitted to Planetary and Space Science). Surface emissivity was derived from MGS TES data, and then binned at a spatial resolution of 8 pixels-per-degree. The binned surface emissivity was then convolved to THEMIS spectral bandpasses between bands 3-9 (~7.9 to 12.5 microns). Each map covers the range -180 to 180 degrees longitude, and -70 to 70 degrees latitude. Null data values are set to zero. A longitudinal offset of 0.271 degrees was applied so that the maps align with data sets that use the IAU 2000 prime meridian. These products may be uploaded as custom maps into the JMARS GIS software. Date of ASU ingest: 5/14/24

Layer.Name: swim_thermal_analysis
Layer.Title: Thermal Analysis (SWIM 2.0)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. TES and THEMIS were integrated into a single thermal consistency map, with TES providing near-global coverage and THEMIS contributing at select locations. For regions where only TES data were considered, matches to models of low ATI units over high ATI units were assigned values of +1 and matches to models of high ATI units over low ATI units were assigned values of -1. If no good match to models was found or the top layer thickness of the matched model had a diurnal skin depth of d less than 1, we assigned a value of 0. At locations where THEMIS data was considered, it was compared directly to TES and we applied equivalent criteria when assigning consistency values. In the LPSC products, consideration of THEMIS data did not modify results derived from TES products only. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_radar_surface_pwr_ret
Layer.Title: Radar Surface Power Return (SWIM 2.0)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. The SHARAD surface power was measured and corrected for surface topography using a combination of MOLA and SHARAD surface roughness data. Low power values provide a proxy for the bulk density of the upper ~ 5m. Due to the low density of ice relative to other martian near surface materials, lower power returns are assumed to be consistent with the presence of ice. Consistency values were assigned according to the global power distribution. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_neutron_dataset
Layer.Title: Neutron Dataset (SWIM 2.0)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. Pathare et al. [2018] produced the most definitive global maps to date of near-surface water-equivalent hydrogen in an upper layer (W_up), lower layer (W_dn), and depth (D) to the lower layer. They refined the cross-over technique developed by Feldman et al. [2011] to produce the first maps of self-consistent W_up, W_dn, and D. These W_dn results (expressed in terms of WEH as percentages) were then scaled to fit into the SWIM equation. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_ice_consistency_grtr_5m
Layer.Title: Combined Ice Consistency (>5 meters)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. The ice consistency map is generated by combining all individual consistency maps through the 'SWIM CI[>5m] Equation', i.e., Deep Geomorphology and Radar Dielectric Estimates. The ice consistency map is designed to show where all data sets are consistent or inconsistent with the presense of ice deeper than 5m, indicating the likely presence of ice or lack thereof in that location. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_ice_consistency_combined
Layer.Title: Combined Ice Consistency (SWIM 1.0)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. The ice consistency map is generated by combining all individual consistency maps through the 'SWIM 1.0 Equation', i.e., Neutron, Thermal, Radar Surface Power, Geomorphology, and Radar Dielectric Estimates. The ice consistency map is designed to show where all data sets are consistent or inconsistent with the presence of ice over a combined sensing depth of ~5m, indicating the likely presence of ice or lack thereof in that location. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_ice_consistency_1-5m
Layer.Title: Combined Ice Consistency (1-5 meters)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. The ice consistency map is generated by combining all individual consistency maps through the 'SWIM CI[1-5m] Equation', i.e., Shallow Geomorphology, Radar Surface Power, and Radar Dielectric Estimates. The ice consistency map is designed to show where all data sets are consistent or inconsistent with the presense of ice between 1 and 5m, indicating the likely presence of ice or lack thereof in that location. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_ice_consistency_0-1m
Layer.Title: Combined Ice Consistency (0-1 meters)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. The ice consistency map is generated by combining all individual consistency maps through the 'SWIM CI[0-1m] Equation', i.e., Neutron, Thermal, Shallow Geomorphology, and Radar Surface Power. The ice consistency map is designed to show where all data sets are consistent or inconsistent with the presense of ice over the combined sensing depth of 1m, indicating the likely presence of ice or lack thereof in that location. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_geomorphology
Layer.Title: Geomorphology (SWIM 2.0)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. The geomorphology ice consistency map was generated using new and previous mapping of periglacial and glacial features. For the new mapping, a number of periglacial and glacial features were systematically surveyed between -60-60N. A sampling of 4x4 CTX image mosaics (beta01 from the CalTech Murray Lab) within previously mapped geologic units (Tanaka et al., 2005, USGS SIM 2888) was used to tally the number of observed periglacial and glacial landforms and to extrapolate the observations to the mapped unit boundaries. The number of landforms was then normalized with equal weighting to yield ice consistency values between 0 and 1. Areas with no observed periglacial or glacial features were assigned a value of -1. Areas of more detailed mapping of scallop terrain were assigned a value of 0.75. Previous mapping was also used as input, including glacial features (lobate debris aprons, lineated valley fill, and concentric crater fill; Levy et al., 2014) and pedestal craters (Kadish et al., 2009). Where mapped, glacial features were assigned a value of 1 and pedestal craters a value of 0.75. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: swim_est_dielectric_prop
Layer.Title: Est. Dielectric Properties (SWIM 2.0)
Layer.Abstract: Subsurface Water Ice Mapping (SWIM). Map source https://swim.psi.edu/. To estimate the dielectric properties we found locations where the approximate depth of a subsurface reflector can be estimated based on the surrounding topography then based on that depth and the two-way travel time we calculate the real dielectric permittivity of the unit above the reflector. In regions where this can be done readily, primarily around Lobate Debris Aprons, we simply took these estimates for the whole region. In regions where the dielectric cannot be found as easily we estimate the dielectric at as many points as possible then interpolate between those points across the extent of the reflector. To generate the estimated dielectric properties ice consistency map we applied equation C_rd = ??x*0.5+2.5 to our estimates of the dielectric, effectively mapping lower dielectric to being more consistent with ice. Date of ingest 1/24/24

Layer.Name: cratering_density_mars
Layer.Title: Cratering Density Map (Lagain et al., 2021)
Layer.Abstract: Cratering density map of 90 million craters less than 300 m in diameter detected on the CTX global mosaic by a machine learning algorithm developed at the Space Science and Technology Centre, Curtin University. Colours indicate crater densities of specific diameter ranges: blue: 25?75?m, green: 75?150?m and red: 150?300?m. Source image: cda_0.05_0m_75m_150m_300m_MARS2000_8bit.tif, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-26648-3. Date of ASU ingest 11/28/21.

Layer.Name: usgs_hirise_jezero_ortho_2020
Layer.Title: Terrain Relative Navigation HiRISE Ortho Mosaic
Layer.Abstract: Mars 2020 Terrain Relative Navigation HiRISE Orthorectified Image Mosaic. The Mars 2020 rover will explore Jezero crater, Mars to investigate an ancient delta for evidence of past microbial life and to better understand the geologic history of the region. The landing system onboard Mars 2020 will use technology developed at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) called Terrain Relative Navigation (TRN), which will enable the spacecraft to autonomously avoid hazards (e.g., rock fields, crater rims) that exceed the safety requirements of the landing system. This capability allows small-scale hazards to be present in the landing ellipse, providing greater flexibility in selecting a landing location. In support of TRN, the USGS Astrogeology Science Center has generated and delivered a High-Resolution Imaging Science Experiment (HiRISE) digital terrain model (DTM) mosaic and orthomosaic that is the basemap onto which surface hazards were mapped. The hazard map will be onboard the spacecraft and used by TRN to help identify the final, hazard-free landing location. This mosaic is available on this site, along with the individual HiRISE orthorectified images that make up the mosaic and the HiRISE DTMs used to derive the orthorectified images. Source image: https://planetarymaps.usgs.gov/mosaic/mars2020_trn/HiRISE/JEZ_hirise_soc_006_orthoMosaic_25cm_Eqc_latTs0_lon0_first.tif Date of ingest 9/21/20

Layer.Name: usgs_hirise_jezero_dtm_2020
Layer.Title: Terrain Relative Navigation HiRISE DTM Mosaic
Layer.Abstract: Mars 2020 Terrain Relative Navigation HiRISE DTM Mosaic. The Mars 2020 rover will explore Jezero crater, Mars to investigate an ancient delta for evidence of past microbial life and to better understand the geologic history of the region. The landing system onboard Mars 2020 will use technology developed at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JP/L) called Terrain Relative Navigation (TRN), which will enable the spacecraft to autonomously avoid hazards (e.g., rock fields, crater rims) that exceed the safety requirements of the landing system. This capability allows small-scale hazards to be present in the landing ellipse, providing greater flexibility in selecting a landing location. In support of TRN, the USGS Astrogeology Science Center has generated and delivered a High-Resolution Imaging Science Experiment (HiRISE) digital terrain model (DTM) mosaic and orthomosaic that is the basemap onto which surface hazards were mapped. The hazard map will be onboard the spacecraft and used by TRN to help identify the final, hazard-free landing location. This mosaic is available on this site, along with the individual HiRISE DTM images that make up the mosaic and the HiRISE orthomosaic and orthorectified images that were derived from this DTM. Source image: https://planetarymaps.usgs.gov/mosaic/mars2020_trn/HiRISE/JEZ_hirise_soc_006_DTM_MOLAtopography_DeltaGeoid_1m_Eqc_latTs0_lon0_blend40.tif Date of ingest 9/21/20

Layer.Name: usgs_ctx_jezero_ortho_2020
Layer.Title: Terrain Relative Navigation CTX Ortho Mosaic
Layer.Abstract: Mars 2020 Terrain Relative Navigation Context Camera Orthorectified Image Mosaic. This is a visible image mosaic generated from the Context Camera (CTX) images from the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter mission. This product is the Lander Visions System (LVS) map that will be onboard the spacecraft and will be the truth dataset that TRN will use to orient itself relative to the surface during Entry, Decent, and Landing. The images were orthorectified using digital terrain models (DTMs) created from CTX stereo images. The mosaic is generated at the same resolution at which the individual CTX images were acquired, which is approximately 6 meters per pixel. This mosaic was created in support of the Mars 2020 rover, which will explore Jezero crater, Mars to investigate an ancient delta for evidence of past microbial life and to better understand the geologic history of the region. The landing system onboard Mars 2020 will use technology developed at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) called Terrain Relative Navigation (TRN), which will enable the spacecraft to autonomously avoid hazards (e.g., rock fields, crater rims) that exceed the safety requirements of the landing system. This capability allows small-scale hazards to be present in the landing ellipse, providing greater flexibility in selecting a landing location. In support of TRN, the USGS Astrogeology Science Center has generated and delivered this product, which is the Lander Vision System (LVS) map. This mosaic is available on this site, along with the individual CTX orthorectified images that make up the mosaic and the CTX DTMs used to derive the orthorectified images. Source image: https://planetarymaps.usgs.gov/mosaic/mars2020_trn/CTX/JEZ_ctx_B_soc_008_orthoMosaic_6m_Eqc_latTs0_lon0.tif, Date of ingest 9/22/20

Layer.Name: usgs_ctx_jezero_dtm_2020
Layer.Title: Terrain Relative Navigation CTX DTM Mosaic
Layer.Abstract: Mars 2020 Terrain Relative Navigation CTX DTM Mosaic. The Mars 2020 rover will explore Jezero crater, Mars to investigate an ancient delta for evidence of past microbial life and to better understand the geologic history of the region. The landing system onboard Mars 2020 will use technology developed at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) called Terrain Relative Navigation (TRN), which will enable the spacecraft to autonomously avoid hazards (e.g., rock fields, crater rims) that exceed the safety requirements of the landing system. This capability allows small-scale hazards to be present in the landing ellipse, providing greater flexibility in selecting a landing location. In support of TRN, the USGS Astrogeology Science Center has generated and delivered the Lander Vision System (LVS) map generated from three Context Camera (CTX) orthorectified images that will be onboard the spacecraft and will be the truth dataset that TRN will use to orient itself relative to the surface during Entry, Decent, and Landing.This mosaic is available on this site, along with the individual CTX DTM images that make up the mosaic and the CTX orthomosaic and orthorectified images that were derived from this DTM. Source image: https://planetarymaps.usgs.gov/mosaic/mars2020_trn/CTX/JEZ_ctx_B_soc_008_DTM_MOLAtopography_DeltaGeoid_20m_Eqc_latTs0_lon0.tif, Date of ingest 9/22/20

Layer.Name: HRSC_MC20W_HMC_DT5
Layer.Title: Spheroid DTM - MC20W HMC DT5
Layer.Abstract: Spheroid DTM product. The HRSC Mars Chart (HMC30) products include multi-orbit digital terrains models (DTMs) and ortho-rectified image mosaics derived from HRSC images, as well as follow-up data products such as pan-sharpened versions of the color image mosaics, color-coded shaded relief maps of the DTMs, and ready to print map sheets of the Topographic Map Series Mars 1: 700,000. http://hrscteam.dlr.de/HMC30, https://maps.planet.fu-berlin.de, http://hrscteam.dlr.de/HMC30/HMC30_tiling_scheme_and_file_naming.pdf, Date of ASU ingest: 12/21/20

Layer.Name: HRSC_MC20W_HMC_DA5
Layer.Title: Areroid DTM - MC20W HMC DA5
Layer.Abstract: Areroid DTM product. The HRSC Mars Chart (HMC30) products include multi-orbit digital terrains models (DTMs) and ortho-rectified image mosaics derived from HRSC images, as well as follow-up data products such as pan-sharpened versions of the color image mosaics, color-coded shaded relief maps of the DTMs, and ready to print map sheets of the Topographic Map Series Mars 1: 700,000. http://hrscteam.dlr.de/HMC30, https://maps.planet.fu-berlin.de, http://hrscteam.dlr.de/HMC30/HMC30_tiling_scheme_and_file_naming.pdf, Date of ASU ingest: 12/21/20

Layer.Name: mola_hrsc_blend_topo_v2
Layer.Title: HRSC MOLA Blended DEM 200m v2
Layer.Abstract: This data product, now at version 2, is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA), an instrument aboard NASA?s Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC), an instrument aboard the European Space Agency?s Mars Express spacecraft. This was created in support of thermal modelling studies and product creation for Mars (Ferguson 2017; Laura 2016). MOLA fired infrared laser pulses downward 10 times per second, and measured the time it took for the reflected pulses to return from the surface. The image used for the MOLA base of this map represents more than 600 million measurements gathered between 1999 and 2001. The average accuracy of each point is originally ~100 meters in horizontal position and the total elevation uncertainty is at least 3 m. MOLA produced global topographic coverage with a spatial resolution of about 300 x 1000 m at the equator, and better near the poles. HRSC, the only dedicated stereo camera orbiting Mars, is a multi-sensor push broom instrument comprising 9 CCD line sensors mounted in parallel for simultaneous high-resolution stereo, multicolor and multi-phase imaging by delivering 9 superimposed image swaths. The HRSC design permits stereo imaging with triple to quintuple panchromatic along-track stereo including a nadir-directed, forward and aft-looking (+/-18.91), and 2 inner (+/-12.81) stereo line sensors. The along-track acquisition of stereo imagery avoids changes in atmospheric and illumination conditions. The sub-pixel accuracy of the three-dimensional point determination allows the derivation of digital elevation models DEMs with a grid size of up to 50 m and a height accuracy of a single pixel with up to 10 m. Source file: https://planetarymaps.usgs.gov/mosaic/Mars/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp_v2.tif, Data ingest 5/7/19

Layer.Name: mola_hrsc_blend_slope_v2
Layer.Title: HRSC MOLA Blended DEM Slope (200m) v2
Layer.Abstract: This data product, now at version 2, is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM,/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument aboard NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. ASU personnel used this DEM in conjunction with the USGS/ISIS slpmap utility to produce this slope product. Units are [0,90] degrees. https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/search/map/Mars/Topography/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp_v2, Data ingest 5/7/19

Layer.Abstract: This data product, now at version 2, is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM,/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument aboard NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. ASU personnel used this DEM in conjunction with the USGS/ISIS shade utility to produce this shaded-relief product where azimuth=135 and zenith=75. https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/search/map/Mars/Topography/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp_v2, Data ingest 5/7/19

Layer.Name: mola_hrsc_blend_shade
Layer.Title: HRSC/MOLA Blend, Shaded Relief (200m)
Layer.Abstract: This hillshade map was created using the ISIS shade utility with azimuth=135 and zenith=75. The source image is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM,/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument aboard NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/search/map/Mars/Topography/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp, Data ingest 10/12/17

Layer.Name: mola_hrsc_blend_merge
Layer.Title: HRSC/MOLA Blend, Grayscale Relief (200m)
Layer.Abstract: This map was produced by combining separate hillshade and gray-scale topography images. The hillshade was created using the ISIS shade utility with azimuth=135 and zenith=75. The gray-scale topography image assigns smaller DN values to lower elevations and larger DN values to to higher elevations, and it was created using the ASU davinci utility. The purpose of the combined map was to provide users with additional visual elevation information beyond a simple hillshade. The source image is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM,/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument aboard NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/search/map/Mars/Topography/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp, Data ingest 10/12/17

Layer.Name: mola_hrsc_blend_color
Layer.Title: HRSC/MOLA Blend, Colorized Relief (200m)
Layer.Abstract: This map was produced by combining separate hillshade and colorized topography images. The hillshade was created using the ISIS shade utility with azimuth=135 and zenith=75. The colorized topography was created using the ASU davinci utility. The source image is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM,/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument aboard NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/search/map/Mars/Topography/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp, Data ingest 10/12/17

Layer.Name: mola_hrsc_blend_azimuth

The source image is a blend of digital elevation model (DEM,/DTM) data derived from the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument aboard NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft (MGS), and the High-Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/search/map/Mars/Topography/HRSC_MOLA_Blend/Mars_HRSC_MOLA_BlendDEM_Global_200mp, Data ingest 10/12/17

Layer.Name: ctx_dtm_P14_006633_2018_P17_007556_2012
Layer.Title: ctx_dtm_P14_006633_2018_P17_007556_2012
Layer.Abstract: CTX Digital Terrain Model of Candidate Mars 2020 Landing Site Nili Fossae Center. This digital terrain model (DTM) was produced as part of an effort to characterize topography within candidate landing ellipses for the Mars2020 mission and to aid entry, descent, and landing simulations for the mission. The DTM was constructed from a pair of CTX images using the stereo photogrammetry software SOCET SET (BAE Systems). The DTM has been used to orthorectify the input images at 6 meters/pixel and to calculate topographic slopes at a 20 meter baseline. ISIS null values were replaced with -2000.0. Data ASU ingest 11/28/17

Layer.Name: ctx_mosaic_zephyria_usgs
Layer.Title: Zephyria Mosaic (USGS)
Layer.Abstract: The USGS created 39 regional semi-controlled CTX mosaics at 5m/pixel for the 2015 proposed Mars Human Exploration zones. Cosmetically, mosaics will have hard edges between images due to seasonal, time, and calibration differences. The processing approach to generate the mosaics used the USGS digital cartographic system ISIS, Arizona State University's Davinci software, and Esri's ArcMap. Integrated Software for Imagers and Spectrometers (ISIS) to ingest images in an archival format and perform instrument-specific radiometric calibration and map project the images. Davinci was used to stretch the images using a running standrd devation to try to remove a ramped (smile) lightening effect in many of the CTX images. This was not always successful and thus mosaics will have hard edges. ArcMap was then used to create a virtual mosaic and then control the images (block adjustment) to each other in an attempt to align features across edges. These images were not controlled to a basemap (e.g. MOLA topographic data or THEMIS controlled mosaic).

Layer.Name: ctx_mosaic_viking_usgs
Layer.Title: Viking Mosaic (USGS)
Layer.Abstract: The USGS created 39 regional semi-controlled CTX mosaics at 5m/pixel for the 2015 proposed Mars Human Exploration zones. Cosmetically, mosaics will have hard edges between images due to seasonal, time, and calibration differences. The processing approach to generate the mosaics used the USGS digital cartographic system ISIS, Arizona State University's Davinci software, and Esri's ArcMap. Integrated Software for Imagers and Spectrometers (ISIS) to ingest images in an archival format and perform instrument-specific radiometric calibration and map project the images. Davinci was used to stretch the images using a running standrd devation to try to remove a ramped (smile) lightening effect in many of the CTX images. This was not always successful and thus mosaics will have hard edges. ArcMap was then used to create a virtual mosaic and then control the images (block adjustment) to each other in an attempt to align features across edges. These images were not controlled to a basemap (e.g. MOLA topographic data or THEMIS controlled mosaic).

Layer.Title: Copernicus Crater Mosaic (USGS)
Layer.Abstract: The USGS created 39 regional semi-controlled CTX mosaics at 5m/pixel for the 2015 proposed Mars Human Exploration zones. Cosmetically, mosaics will have hard edges between images due to seasonal, time, and calibration differences. The processing approach to generate the mosaics used the USGS digital cartographic system ISIS, Arizona State University's Davinci software, and Esri's ArcMap. Integrated Software for Imagers and Spectrometers (ISIS) to ingest images in an archival format and perform instrument-specific radiometric calibration and map project the images. Davinci was used to stretch the images using a running standrd devation to try to remove a ramped (smile) lightening effect in many of the CTX images. This was not always successful and thus mosaics will have hard edges. ArcMap was then used to create a virtual mosaic and then control the images (block adjustment) to each other in an attempt to align features across edges. These images were not controlled to a basemap (e.g. MOLA topographic data or THEMIS controlled mosaic).

Layer.Name: mars_thermophysical_categories_numeric
Layer.Title: Thermophysical Units (Numeric)
Layer.Abstract: This data product maps thermophysical units derived from Martian Thermal Inertia and Albedo. The numeric source map is described in (Jones, E., Caprarelli, G., Mills, F., Doran, B., and Clarke, J. (2014) An alternative approach to mapping thermophysical units from Martian thermal inertia and albedo data using a combination of unsupervised classification techniques. Remote Sensing, 6(6), 5184-5237.). In this numeric version, the seven individual units are represented as integers 1-7. Non-data areas are colored black. Data ingest 4/7/16.

Layer.Name: mars_thermophysical_categories
Layer.Title: Thermophysical Units (Colorized)
Layer.Abstract: This data product is a colorized map of thermophysical units derived from Martian Thermal Inertia and Albedo. The numeric source map is described in (Jones, E., Caprarelli, G., Mills, F., Doran, B., and Clarke, J. (2014) An alternative approach to mapping thermophysical units from Martian thermal inertia and albedo data using a combination of unsupervised classification techniques. Remote Sensing, 6(6), 5184-5237.). In this colorized version, the seven individual units (1-7) are represented by the colors Blue, Lime-Green, Magenta, Yellow, Purple, Orange and Red. Non-data areas are colored black. Data ingest 4/7/16. Colorized image created by ASU personnel.

Layer.Name: mars_min_wind
Layer.Title: Annual Minumum Wind Speed
Layer.Abstract: Annual (average/maximum/minimum) wind speed (m/s) (vector magnitude). Wind vectors output from the Ames GCM, run09.41; a c-grid run with TES dust opacity map (Mars year 26). The winds are taken from the mid-point of the bottom atmosphere layer, which is approximately 5 meters above the surface. Hollingsworth, J., R. Haberle et al. NASA Ames GCM run09.41. Date of map ingest 3/4/16

Layer.Name: mars_yearly_minimum_temperature_celsius
Layer.Title: Yearly Mars Surface Minimum Temperature (C)
Layer.Abstract: This map contains the minimum yearly surface temperature as computed by KRC version 2.3.2 running in single point mode using MGS/TES albedo. Using a script that calls KRC in point-source mode, 36 maps were generated for local times 5 am and 1 pm, and Ls 0-360 (10 degree increments). For each pixel, the annual maximum and minimum temperatures were calculated. The annual variation (max-min) and the annual average (approximate, [day+night]/2) were calculated. Map redeployed with Celsius values. Map ingest: 4/28/20

Layer.Name: mars_yearly_avg_temperature_celsius

These statistical temperature maps are intended for use with JMARS 2035 for human landing site assessment. Using a script that calls KRC in point-source mode, 36 maps were generated for local times 5 am and 1 pm, and Ls 0-360 (10 degree increments). For each pixel, the annual maximum and minimum temperatures were calculated. The annual variation (max-min) and the annual average (approximate, [day+night]/2) were calculated. Map redeployed with Celsius values. Map ingest: 4/28/20

Layer.Name: thm_nir_100m_v13_3
Layer.Title: THEMIS Night IR 100m Global Mosaic (v14.0)
Layer.Abstract: This product is a global mosaic of Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS) nighttime infrared Band 9 (12.57um) images of Mars acquired at 100m/pixel resolution. The individual images have been stretched using a running stretch algorithm and were then blended together to reduce the appearance of seams between images. The global mosaic is composed of 18,931 THEMIS nighttime infrared images.

Layer.Name: thm_dir_100m_v11_11
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR 100m Global Mosaic (v12.0)
Layer.Abstract: This product is a global mosaic of Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS) daytime infrared Band 9 (12.57um) images of Mars acquired at 100m/pixel resolution. The individual images have been stretched using a running stretch algorithm and were then blended together to reduce the appearance of seams between images. The global mosaic is composed of 24,530 THEMIS daytime infrared images.

Layer.Name: thm_dir_100m_v13_4
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR 100m Global Mosaic v13.4
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR 100 meter/pixel Global Mosaic version 13.4. This product was created by the staff of the Mars Space Flight Facility at Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA. This daytime infrared relative temperature mosaic is composed of 26,204 images acquired during the first ~15 years of the Mars Odyssey mission. For details regarding the creation of this global mosaic, reference: Hill, J. R., and P. R. Christensen (2017),Well-preserved low thermal inertia ejecta deposits surrounding young secondary impact craters on Mars,J. Geophys. Res. Planets, 122, 1276?1299,doi:10.1002/2016JE005210 and the references cited within. This product was produced by J.R. Hill and finalized on May 8, 2020.

Layer.Name: thm_dirnir_100m_v13_4
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR with Colorized Night IR v13.4
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR with Colorized Night IR 100 meter/pixel Global Mosaic version 13.4. This product was created by the staff of the Mars Space Flight Facility at Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA. The daytime infrared relative temperature mosaic basemap is composed of 26,204 images acquired during the first ~15 years of the Mars Odyssey mission. The nighttime infrared relative temperature mosaic is composed of 18,931 images acquired during the first ~13 years of the Mars Odyssey mission. The nighttime mosaic only covers 60N-60S because the definition of "night" (the surface is heated during the day and the THEMIS images measure how it has cooled off at night) being used breaks down poleward of 60deg, since the surface is often in either permanent day or permanent night, which makes it difficult to measure how the surface cools off after the sun sets. At a future date, the Night IR Global Mosaic will be updated to include all available nighttime infrared images to-date and an updated version of this product will be produced and released. This product is a combination of the THEMIS Day IR 100m Global Mosaic (v13.4) and the THEMIS Night IR 100m Global Mosaic (v14.0) and is composed of a combined total of 45,135 THEMIS images. The Night IR Global Mosaic was colorized using a binning appraoch (6 bins/colors) and then the RGB bands were individually multiplied by the Day IR Global Mosaic to generate this final product. For details regarding the creation of this global mosaic, reference: Hill, J. R., and P. R. Christensen (2017),Well-preserved low thermal inertia ejecta deposits surrounding young secondary impact craters on Mars,J. Geophys. Res. Planets, 122, 1276?1299,doi:10.1002/2016JE005210 and the references cited within. This product was produced by J.R. Hill and finalized on May 11, 2020.

Layer.Name: thm_dirmola_100m_v13_4
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR with Colorized MOLA Elevation v13.4
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR with Colorized MOLA Elevation 100 meter/pixel Global Mosaic version 13.4. This product was created by the staff of the Mars Space Flight Facility at Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA. The daytime infrared relative temperature mosaic basemap is composed of 26,204 images acquired during the first ~15 years of the Mars Odyssey mission. The MOLA global elevation map was acquired during the first ~4 years of the Mars Global Surveyor mission. The MOLA elevation data was colorized using the standard MOLA color scheme and linear binning between -8,000m and +14,000m. Each of the resulting RGB bands was then multiplied by a shaded relief map generated from the MOLA elevation data and illuminated from the west, roughly replicating the illumination conditions at the local time observed by THEMIS. The resulting colorized shaded relief map was then converted into HSV space, the value was increased by 50% and then converted back to RGB space, in order to make the colorization more visibly appealing. The RGB bands of the colorized shaded relief map were then multiplied by the THEMIS Day IR global mosaic. The resulting map was then converted into HSV space, the saturation was decreased by 20%, the value was increased by 75%, and then converted back into RGB space. These color adjustments were performed to make the final product more visually appealing. This product uses the THEMIS Day IR 100m Global Mosaic (v13.4) as the basemap. For details regarding the creation of this global mosaic, reference: Hill, J. R., and P. R. Christensen (2017),Well-preserved low thermal inertia ejecta deposits surrounding young secondary impact craters on Mars,J. Geophys. Res. Planets, 122, 1276?1299,doi:10.1002/2016JE005210 and the references cited within. This product was produced by J.R. Hill and finalized on May 18, 2020.

Layer.Name: thm_ti_100m_32bit
Layer.Title: THEMIS Quantitative Thermal Inertia 100m Global Mosaic (32-bit)
Layer.Abstract: This product is a mosaic of Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS)-derived global thermal inertia images of Mars at 100 m per pixel spatial scales. Apparent thermal inertia values in quantitative (32-bit) mosaics are unmodified during the mosaicking process and are therefore suitable for scientific investigation.

Layer.Name: thm_ti_100m_8bit
Layer.Title: THEMIS Thermal Inertia 100m Global Mosaic (8-bit)
Layer.Abstract: This product is a mosaic of Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS)-derived global thermal inertia images of Mars at 100 m per pixel spatial scales. The 8-bit products are normalized to remove any image-to-image variations resulting in a seamless final product. In addition, the individual images and tiles have been normalized in such a way that multiple tiles can be downloaded and mosaicked together without noticeable seams between tiles.

Layer.Name: themis_thaumasia_nightir
Layer.Title: Thaumasia Night IR Controlled Mosaic
Layer.Abstract: This product is an infrared image mosaic generated using Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS) images from the 2001 Mars Odyssey orbiter mission. The mosaic is generated at the full resolution of the THEMIS infrared dataset, which is approximately 100 meters/pixel. The mosaic was registered horizontally to an improved Viking MDIM network that was develop by the USGS Astrogeology cartography group. This work is funded by the Planetary Geology and Geophysics (PGG) Cartography program to improve the registration of the THEMIS infrared dataset. These controlled mosaics and improved image pointing knowledge will positively impact both the work performed by the Astrogeology cartography group and a broad range of disciplines within the larger science community. Controlled THEMIS mosaics will benefit geologic mapping efforts (superior basemap), landed science operations (site characterization and traverse planning), and orbital observation planning (precision targeting). The control networks that result constitute a (potentially global) framework for the precision cartographic control of existing and future higher spatial resolution data products (e.g. CTX), and will allow the registration of historical data sets to be improved. In addition, the preliminary smithed kernels will be very valuable to scientists and allow them to perform quantitative analyses with THEMIS images using improved pointing knowledge as well as the precision and accuracy of that knowledge. Data source: https://astrogeology.usgs.gov/maps/mars-themis-controlled-mosaics-and-preliminary-smithed-kernels. Date of map ingest 10/31/17

Layer.Name: themis_arcadia_nightir
Layer.Title: Arcadia Night IR Controlled Mosaic
Layer.Abstract: This product is an infrared image mosaic generated using Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS) images from the 2001 Mars Odyssey orbiter mission. The mosaic is generated at the full resolution of the THEMIS infrared dataset, which is approximately 100 meters/pixel. The mosaic was registered horizontally to an improved Viking MDIM network that was develop by the USGS Astrogeology cartography group. This work is funded by the Planetary Geology and Geophysics (PGG) Cartography program to improve the registration of the THEMIS infrared dataset. These controlled mosaics and improved image pointing knowledge will positively impact both the work performed by the Astrogeology cartography group and a broad range of disciplines within the larger science community. Controlled THEMIS mosaics will benefit geologic mapping efforts (superior basemap), landed science operations (site characterization and traverse planning), and orbital observation planning (precision targeting). The control networks that result constitute a (potentially global) framework for the precision cartographic control of existing and future higher spatial resolution data products (e.g. CTX), and will allow the registration of historical data sets to be improved. In addition, the preliminary smithed kernels will be very valuable to scientists and allow them to perform quantitative analyses with THEMIS images using improved pointing knowledge as well as the precision and accuracy of that knowledge. Layer.Name: omega_pyroxene_bd2000
Layer.Title: OMEGA Band depth at 2000 nm, Ody et al 2012
Layer.Abstract: DATA_SET_ID = MEX-M-OMEGA-5-DDR-GLOBAL-MAPS-V1.0, PRODUCT_ID = PYROXENE_BD2000_EQU_MAP, RELEASE_ID = 0001, REVISION_ID = 0000, PROCESSING_LEVEL_ID = 5, PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2013-08-28T17:36:18.000, INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID = MEX, INSTRUMENT_HOST_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, INSTRUMENT_ID = OMEGA, INSTRUMENT_NAME = Observatoire Mineralogie, Eau, Glaces, Activite, MISSION_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, TARGET_NAME = MARS, START_TIME = 2004-01-08T12:46:15.000, STOP_TIME = 2010-08-20T00:46:05.000, START_ORBIT_NUMBER = 6, STOP_ORBIT_NUMBER = 8485. This data product is a global pyroxene spectral parameter map of Mars at a resolution of 40 ppd (about 1.5 km at the equator). It is based on reflectance data acquired by the Mars Express OMEGA hyperspectral camera from January 2004 to August 2010. The OMEGA Flight Experiment Data Records (EDR) are the source for this data product. It corresponds to the map that was produced and published by Ody et al. ([ODY_JGR2012], figure 7d). This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the highest value of the pyroxene spectral parameter values calculated within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. This pyroxene spectral parameter (BD2000) is based on its 2 micrometer absorption band due to both high-calcium and low-calcium pyroxene. For more information on how this map was produced and how it can be best interpreted, please refer to the original publication available in the DOCUMENT directory of this data set.

Layer.Name: omega_olivine_osp3
Layer.Title: OMEGA Olivine 1360nm band, Ody et al 2012
Layer.Abstract: DATA_SET_ID = MEX-M-OMEGA-5-DDR-GLOBAL-MAPS-V1.0, PRODUCT_ID = OLIVINE_OSP3_EQU_MAP, RELEASE_ID = 0001, REVISION_ID = 0000, PROCESSING_LEVEL_ID = 5, PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2013-08-28T17:36:09.000, INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID = MEX, INSTRUMENT_HOST_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, INSTRUMENT_ID = OMEGA, INSTRUMENT_NAME = Observatoire Mineralogie, Eau, Glaces, Activite, MISSION_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, TARGET_NAME = MARS, START_TIME = 2004-01-08T12:46:15.000, STOP_TIME = 2010-08-20T00:46:05.000, START_ORBIT_NUMBER = 6, STOP_ORBIT_NUMBER = 8485. This data product is a global olivine spectral parameter map of Mars at a resolution of 40 ppd (about 1.5 km at the equator). It is based on reflectance data acquired by the Mars Express OMEGA hyperspectral camera from January 2004 to August 2010. The OMEGA Flight Experiment Data Records (EDR) are the source for this data product. It corresponds to the map that was produced and published by Ody et al. ([ODY_JGR2012], figure 9a). This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the highest value of the olive spectral parameter values calculated within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. Olivine has a broad, complex absorption centered near 1 micrometer that varies in width, position, and shape with grain size and Fo number. This olivine spectral parameter (OSP3) determines the full band depth at 1.36 micrometer relative to a continuum. It preferentially detects olivine with a large Fe content and/or with large grain size and/or with high abundance. For more information on how this map was produced and how it can be best interpreted, please refer to the original publication available in the DOCUMENT directory of this data set.

This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the highest value of the olive spectral parameter values calculated within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. Olivine has a broad, complex absorption centered near 1 micrometer that varies in width, position, and shape with grain size and Fo number. This olivine spectral parameter (OSP2) is sensitive to olivine with high iron content and/or large grain size and/or high abundance. For more information on how this map was produced and how it can be best interpreted, please refer to the original publication available in the DOCUMENT directory of this data set.

It is based on reflectance data acquired by the Mars Express OMEGA hyperspectral camera from January 2004 to August 2010. The OMEGA Flight Experiment Data Records (EDR) are the source for this data product. It corresponds to the map that was produced and published by Ody et al. ([ODY_JGR2012], figure 9a). This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the highest value of the olive spectral parameter values calculated within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. Olivine has a broad, complex absorption centered near 1 micrometer that varies in width, position, and shape with grain size and Fo number. This olivine spectral parameter (OSP1) detects Mg-rich and/or small grain size and/or low abundance olivine. For more information on how this map was produced and how it can be best interpreted, please refer to the original publication available in the DOCUMENT directory of this data set.

Layer.Name: omega_ferric_nnphs
Layer.Title: OMEGA Ferric/Dust 860nm ratio, Ody et al 2012
Layer.Abstract: DATA_SET_ID = MEX-M-OMEGA-5-DDR-GLOBAL-MAPS-V1.0, PRODUCT_ID = FERRIC_NNPHS_EQU_MAP, RELEASE_ID = 0001, REVISION_ID = 0000, PROCESSING_LEVEL_ID = 5, PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2013-08-28T17:35:42.000, INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID = MEX, INSTRUMENT_HOST_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, INSTRUMENT_ID = OMEGA, INSTRUMENT_NAME = Observatoire Mineralogie, Eau, Glaces, Activite, MISSION_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, TARGET_NAME = MARS, START_TIME = 2004-01-08T12:46:15.000, STOP_TIME = 2010-08-20T00:46:05.000, START_ORBIT_NUMBER = 6, STOP_ORBIT_NUMBER = 8485. This data product is a global nanophase ferric oxide (dust) spectral parameter map of Mars at a resolution of 40 ppd (about 1.5 km at the equator). It is based on reflectance data acquired by the Mars Express OMEGA hyperspectral camera from January 2004 to August 2010. The OMEGA Flight Experiment Data Records (EDR) are the source for this data product. It corresponds to the map that was produced and published by Ody et al. ([ODY_JGR2012], figure 7c). This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the highest value of the nanophase ferric oxide spectral parameter values calculated within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. This nanophase ferric oxide spectral parameter (NNPHS) is based on the absorption feature centered at 0.86 micrometer. For more information on how this map was produced and how it can be best interpreted, please refer to the original publication available in the DOCUMENT directory of this data set.

Layer.Name: omega_ferric_bd530
Layer.Title: OMEGA Ferric edge 530nm, Ody et al 2012
Layer.Abstract: DATA_SET_ID = MEX-M-OMEGA-5-DDR-GLOBAL-MAPS-V1.0, PRODUCT_ID = FERRIC_BD530_EQU_MAP, RELEASE_ID = 0001, REVISION_ID = 0000, PROCESSING_LEVEL_ID = 5, PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2013-08-28T17:35:32.000, INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID = MEX, INSTRUMENT_HOST_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, INSTRUMENT_ID = OMEGA, INSTRUMENT_NAME = Observatoire Mineralogie, Eau, Glaces, Activite, MISSION_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, TARGET_NAME = MARS, START_TIME = 2004-01-08T12:46:15.000, STOP_TIME = 2010-08-20T00:46:05.000, START_ORBIT_NUMBER = 6, STOP_ORBIT_NUMBER = 8485. This data product is a global ferric oxide spectral parameter map of Mars at a resolution of 40 ppd (about 1.5 km at the equator). It is based on reflectance data acquired by the Mars Express OMEGA hyperspectral camera from January 2004 to August 2010. The OMEGA Flight Experiment Data Records (EDR) are the source for this data product. It corresponds to the map that was produced and published by Ody et al. ([ODY_JGR2012], figure 7b). This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the highest value of the ferric oxide spectral parameter values calculated within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. This ferric oxide spectral parameter (DB530) is based on the strength of the 0.53 micrometer ferric absorption edge. For more information on how this map was produced and how it can be best interpreted, please refer to the original publication available in the DOCUMENT directory of this data set.

Layer.Name: omega_albedo_r1080
Layer.Title: OMEGA Est. Lambert Albedo 1080nm, Ody et al 2012
Layer.Abstract: DATA_SET_ID = MEX-M-OMEGA-5-DDR-GLOBAL-MAPS-V1.0, PRODUCT_ID = ALBEDO_R1080_EQU_MAP, RELEASE_ID = 0001, REVISION_ID = 0000, PROCESSING_LEVEL_ID = 5, PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2013-08-28T17:35:22.000, INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID = MEX, INSTRUMENT_HOST_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, INSTRUMENT_ID = OMEGA, INSTRUMENT_NAME = Observatoire Mineralogie, Eau, Glaces, Activite, MISSION_NAME = MARS EXPRESS, TARGET_NAME = MARS, START_TIME = 2004-01-08T12:46:15.000, STOP_TIME = 2010-08-20T00:46:05.000, START_ORBIT_NUMBER = 6, STOP_ORBIT_NUMBER = 8485. This data product is a global NIR 1-micrometer albedo map of Mars at a resolution of 40 ppd (about 1.5 km at the equator). It is based on reflectance data acquired by the Mars Express OMEGA hyperspectral camera from January 2004 to August 2010. The OMEGA Flight Experiment Data Records (EDR) are the source for this data product. It corresponds to the map that was produced and published by Ody et al. ([ODY_JGR2012], figure 7a). This map, in simple cylindrical projection, is in the form of an image where each sample represents the average value of albedo values within a 0.025 by 0.025 degree area. Albedo (R1080) is calculated using I/F / cos(i) value at 1.08 micrometer (with i the solar incidence angle), assuming a lambertian surface.

Layer.Name: omega_pyroxene_map
Layer.Title: OMEGA Pyroxene Map
Layer.Abstract: Like olivine, pyroxene results from volcanic processes that trace the evolution of the planet?s interior, its chemical composition acting as a tracer of the evolution of the temperature and pressure inside the planet. Pyroxenes are particularly widespread in the cratered highlands, pointing to some of the most ancient portions of the planet?s crust. In the smooth northern plains, the pyroxenes reflect the eruption of more evolved lavas compared to the pristine magnesium-rich olivines. The change in composition over time suggests that older lavas may have had higher temperatures than younger lavas. The colour scale represents the abundance of pyroxene, from low (blue) to high (red). Credits: ESA/CNES/CNRS/IAS/Universit Paris-Sud, Orsay; Background image: NASA MOLA

Layer.Name: omega_olivine_map
Layer.Title: OMEGA Olivine Map
Layer.Abstract: Olivine and pyroxene tell the story of volcanism, with differences in the chemical composition of the solidified lavas representing the evolution of the temperature and pressure inside the planet. Some of the most pristine olivines are found around impact craters that have excavated very ancient samples of the mantle from below the crust. Most of the olivine-rich surfaces are associated with a global lava-flooding event around 3.7 billion years ago when magma erupted onto the surface through fractures in the floors of impact craters, forming lava ?seas? similar to the lunar mare. The colour scale indicates a transition in chemical composition of the olivine lavas from magnesium-rich (blue) to iron-rich (red). The signature of olivine is also related to its grain size and abundance, such that the colour scale from blue to red also describes a small (less than 100 microns) to large (a few mm) grain size, and/or a low (10%) to high (40%) abundance in comparison to the mean martian surface. For example, detections mapped in red (such as the prominent spot indicating Nili Fossae) correspond to olivine with high iron content, and/or a large grain size and/or a high abundance. Credits: ESA/CNES/CNRS/IAS/Universit Paris-Sud, Orsay; Background image: NASA MOLA

Layer.Name: omega_hydrated_mineral_map
Layer.Title: OMEGA Hydrated Mineral Map
Layer.Abstract: The localised dots in the map show individual sites where hydrated minerals formed only in the presence of water were detected. More than ten different hydrous minerals have been found on Mars, with many occurrences found in the same site. In total, several thousand individual mineral exposures have been detected on Mars. The detections were made by combining observations made by ESA's Mars Express OMEGA instrument and NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter CRISM instrument. The hydrated sites are found in various geological landscapes. Over 50% are associated with an impact structure ? exposed in their crater walls, floors or central peaks ? that have excavated older material from below. Sedimentary deposits and crustal outcrops account for a little under the remaining half of the occurrences, with ancient river deltas accommodating 5% of the sites. They are primarily seen in the most ancient terrain dating back to over four billion years ago, suggesting that Mars may have sustained surface and subsurface liquid water for the first few hundred million years of its life, providing conditions favourable to life. Credits: ESA/CNES/CNRS/IAS/Universit Paris-Sud, Orsay; NASA/JPL/JHUAPL; Background image: NASA MOLA

Layer.Name: omega_ferric_oxide_map
Layer.Title: OMEGA Ferric Oxide Map
Layer.Abstract: This map, by the OMEGA instrument on ESA?s Mars Express, plots the distribution of ferric oxides, a mineral phase of iron, across the surface of Mars. Ferric oxides (an oxide of iron) are present everywhere on the planet: within the bulk crust, lava outflows and the dust oxidised by chemical reactions with the martian atmosphere. Mars? atmosphere contains both carbon dioxide and water, both of which provide a source of oxygen to react with the iron in the surface. The intensity in colour from blue to red represents the degree of oxidation of the surface from low to high, and therefore is related to the abundance of iron-bearing minerals. Credits: ESA/CNES/CNRS/IAS/Universit Paris-Sud, Orsay; Background image: NASA MOLA

Layer.Name: omega_dust_map
Layer.Title: OMEGA Dust Map
Layer.Abstract: This map, by the OMEGA instrument on ESA?s Mars Express, shows the distribution of dust across the suface of Mars. The dust is in the form of ferric oxide nanoparticles (at most a few tens of nm in size). The particles are thought to be the result of chemical reactions with the atmosphere, causing the surface to ?rust? slowly over billions of years, giving Mars its distinctive red hue. The degree of rusting is also related to the distinct mineral compositions of the crustal rocks from which the dust derived, and is closely linked to iron-rich terrains (including the volcanic province of Tharsis). Weathering and erosion from past glacial activity and impact events, as well as dust storms, winds and freezing and thawing cycles today, contribute to the continued production of fine-grained dust. The colour scale represents the amount of dust present on the surface, from low to high abundance. Credits: ESA/CNES/CNRS/IAS/Universit Paris-Sud, Orsay; Background image: NASA MOLA

Layer.Name: crism_mrdr_band_0045
Layer.Title: IRR3 - Map Projected Multispectral RDR
Layer.Abstract: This 256 ppd global mosaic was assembled from individual Map-projected Multispectral RDR tiles downloaded from the PDS. The 45 band source data tiles were acquired by the Compact Reconnaissance Imaging Spectrometer for Mars (CRISM) instrument on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) spacecraft. Arizona State University personnel used ISIS utilities to separate the 45 band source into this single band mosaic. INSTRUMENT_ID = CRISM, TARGET_NAME = MARS, PRODUCT_TYPE = MAP_PROJECTED_MULTISPECTRAL_RDR, PRODUCER_INSTITUTION_NAME = APPLIED PHYSICS LABORATORY, For more information refer to: http://pds-geosciences.wustl.edu/mro/mro-m-crism-3-rdr-targeted-v1/mrocr_2104/document/crism_dpsis.pdf --- Band: 45, Name: IRR3, Parameter: IR ratio 3, Formulation: R3500 / R3390, Rationale: aphelion ice clouds (higher values) vs. seasonal or dust, Input Data: I/F

Layer.Name: crism_mrdr_band_0044
Layer.Title: BD2700 - Map Projected Multispectral RDR
Layer.Abstract: This 256 ppd global mosaic was assembled from individual Map-projected Multispectral RDR tiles downloaded from the PDS. The 45 band source data tiles were acquired by the Compact Reconnaissance Imaging Spectrometer for Mars (CRISM) instrument on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) spacecraft. Arizona State University personnel used ISIS utilities to separate the 45 band source into this single band mosaic. INSTRUMENT_ID = CRISM, TARGET_NAME = MARS, PRODUCT_TYPE = MAP_PROJECTED_MULTISPECTRAL_RDR, PRODUCER_INSTITUTION_NAME = APPLIED PHYSICS LABORATORY, For more information refer to: http://pds-geosciences.wustl.edu/mro/mro-m-crism-3-rdr-targeted-v1/mrocr_2104/document/crism_dpsis.pdf --- Band: 44, Name: BD2700, Parameter: 2.70 micron CO2 band depth, Formulation: 1 ? ( R2694 / (R2530*(R2530 / R2350)) ), Rationale: atmospheric structure (accounts for spectral slope), Input Data: I/F

Layer.Name: tes_530_index_numeric
Layer.Title: TES 530 Index (Ruff and Christensen, 2007) - Numeric
Layer.Abstract: These indices are designed to search TES spectra for a spectral 'doublet' found in certain dioctahedral clay minerals. Used in tandem, locations on Mars where both indices are elevated may host smectite clays. Used separately, the 465 index serves as a proxy for TES surface type 2 and the 530 index is sensitive to an olivine spectral feature. A full description is given in Ruff and Christensen, 2007 (http://www.agu.org/journals/gl/gl0710/2007GL029602). This paper is available for download using the following login ID and password: 98795779. Please use this citation when using the maps. MOLA shaded relief base courtesy of NASA/JPL/Goddard. Source images are located at http://mars.asu.edu/~ruff/I465_530/i465_530.html

Layer.Name: TES_Lambert_Albedo_mola
Layer.Title: TES Albedo - MOLA drape
Layer.Abstract: TES Surface albedo blended with MOLA Shaded Relief. Citation:Christensen et al., The Mars Global Surveyor Thermal Emission Spectrometer experiment: Investigation description and surface science results, J. Geophys. Res., 106, 23,823-23,871, 2001.. MGS/TES. 8 ppd/7.5km. /afs/.mars.asu.edu/marsmaps/tes_properties_maps/albedo/TES_100129/TES_100129_mola.png. This graphic map shows TES Bolometric Albedo of the surface of Mars blended with MOLA Shaded Relief. Original data, measured at 0.3 to 2.9 micrometers, have been reduced to Lambert Albedo values. See CHRISTENSEN2001 for Lambert Albedo equation. The numeric data for this product is also available (TES_100010).

Layer.Name: thm_dirmola2_100m_v13_4
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR with ASU Color v13.4
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR with ASU Color Scheme based on MOLA Elevation 100 meter/pixel Global Mosaic version 13.4. This product was created by the staff of the Mars Space Flight Facility at Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA. The daytime infrared relative temperature mosaic basemap is composed of 26,204 images acquired during the first ~15 years of the Mars Odyssey mission. The MOLA global elevation map was acquired during the first ~4 years of the Mars Global Surveyor mission. The MOLA elevation data was colorized using a custom color scheme and linear binning between -8,000m and +14,000m. The custom color scheme was developed by Extra Small Design, Inc of Phoenix, AZ. Each of the resulting RGB bands was then multiplied by a shaded relief map generated from the MOLA elevation data and illuminated from the west, roughly replicating the illumination conditions at the local time observed by THEMIS. The RGB bands of the resulting colorized shaded relief map were then multiplied by the THEMIS Day IR global mosaic. This product uses the THEMIS Day IR 100m Global Mosaic (v13.4) as the basemap. For details regarding the creation of this global mosaic, reference: Hill, J. R., and P. R. Christensen (2017), Well-preserved low thermal inertia ejecta deposits surrounding young secondary impact craters on Mars,J. Geophys. Res. Planets, 122, 1276?1299,doi:10.1002/2016JE005210 and the references cited within. This product was produced by J.R. Hill and finalized on August 20, 2020.

Layer.Name: thm_dirmola2_100m_v13_3
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR with ASU Color v13.3
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR 100 meter/pixel Global Mosaic v13.3 with ASU Color Scheme based on MOLA Elevation

Layer.Name: thm_dirmola_100m_v1_1
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR with MOLA Color v13.0
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR 100 meter/pixel Global Mosaic with MOLA Color, with saturation reduced to 80% and value increased to 125%.

Layer.Name: thm_nightir_100m_v13
Layer.Title: THEMIS Night IR 100m Global Mosaic v13
Layer.Abstract: The THEMIS 100m/px relative temperature nighttime global mosaics were created at the Mars Space Flight Facility, at Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA. THEMIS daytime data were selected with the following parameters: shutter closing time less than 150 seconds, incidence angle more then 95 degrees, surface temperature greater than or equal to 160K, 0% saturated pixels from 75S to 75N with unsummed data. Citation: Edwards, C. S., K. J. Nowicki, P. R. Christensen, J. Hill, N. Gorelick, and K. Murray (2011), Mosaicking of global planetary image datasets: 1. Techniques and data processing for Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS) multi-spectral data, J. Geophys. Res., 116, E10008, doi:10.1029/2010JE003755

Layer.Name: thm_dayir_100m_v11
Layer.Title: THEMIS Day IR 100m Global Mosaic v11
Layer.Abstract: THEMIS Day IR 100 meter global mosaic, version 11. The THEMIS 100m/px relative temperature daytime global mosaics were created at the Mars Space Flight Facility, at Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA. THEMIS daytime data were selected with the following parameters: shutter closing time less than 150 seconds, incidence angle less than 85, minimum surface temperature greater than or equal to 160K, 0% saturated pixels from 90S to 90N with unsummed data. Citation: Edwards, C. S., K. J. Nowicki, P. R. Christensen, J. Hill, N. Gorelick, and K. Murray (2011), Mosaicking of global planetary image datasets: 1. Techniques and data processing for Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS) multi-spectral data, J. Geophys. Res., 116, E10008, doi:10.1029/2010JE003755

THEMIS daytime data were selected with the following parameters: shutter closing time less than 150 seconds, incidence angle less than 85, minimum surface temperature greater than or equal to 160K, 0% saturated pixels from 90S to 90N with unsummed data. Citation: Edwards, C. S., K. J. Nowicki, P. R. Christensen, J. Hill, N. Gorelick, and K. Murray (2011), Mosaicking of global planetary image datasets: 1. Layer.Name: tes_nightside_ti_putzig_2005
Layer.Title: TES Nightside Thermal Inertia (20 ppd) (Putzig et. al. 2005)
Layer.Abstract: This is a floating point map of TES nightside thermal inertia product. Values range from 24-800 (J m^-2 K^-1 s^-1/2). This map is derived from the TES thermal bolometer observations using orbits 1583-11254 (primary mapping mission). Only nighttime data are used, for bolometric temperatures above 160 K. The map is an average of binned inertias. Citation: Putzig, N. E., Mellon, M. T., Arvidson, R. E., and Kretke, K. A. (2005), Global thermal inertia and surface properties of Mars from the MGS mapping mission, Icarus, 173, 325-341. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103504002957, Source data file: https://se.psi.edu/inertia/nmap2003.tif, Data ingest: 5/24/18

Layer.Name: tes_nightside_ti_putzig_2005_color
Layer.Title: Colorized TES Nightside Thermal Inertia (20 ppd) (Putzig et. al. 2005)
Layer.Abstract: This is a colorized version of the floating point TES nightside thermal inertia product. Values range from 24-800 (J m^-2 K^-1 s^-1/2), where violet is the minimum, cyan is ~160 and white is the maximum at 800. Citation: Putzig, N. E., Mellon, M. T., Arvidson, R. E., and Kretke, K. A. (2005), Global thermal inertia and surface properties of Mars from the MGS mapping mission, Icarus, 173, 325-341. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103504002957, Source data file: https://se.psi.edu/inertia/nmap2003.tif, Data ingest: 5/24/18

Layer.Name: tes_nightside_ti_putzig_2007_color

Layer.Name: TES_Thermal_Inertia_mola
Layer.Title: TES Thermal Inertia - MOLA drape
Layer.Abstract: TES Thermal Inertia blended with MOLA Shaded Relief. Citation: Christensen et al., The Mars Global Surveyor Thermal Emission Spectrometer experiment: Investigation description and surface science results, J. Geophys. Res., 106, 23,823-23,871, 2001. Colorized thermal inertia from NASA MGS/TES. 8 ppd/7.5km. /afs/.mars.asu.edu/marsmaps/tes_properties_maps/TES_100128/TES_100128_mola.png. This graphic map shows TES thermal inertia of the surface of Mars blended with MOLA Shaded Relief. Maps are derived from TES thermal bolometer data collected between 1997 and 2003. See CHRISTENSEN1992 for more information. The numeric data for this product is also available (TES_100009).

Layer.Name: TES_100103_numeric
Layer.Title: TES Olivine Index Fo75-100 (Koeppen and Hamilton, 2008) - Numeric
Layer.Abstract: TES Olivine Index Fo75-100, Koeppen, W.C. and V. E. Hamilton, Global distribution, composition, and abundance of olivine on the surface of Mars from thermal infrared data, J. Geophys. Res., 113, E05001, doi:10.1029/2007JE002984, 2008. These olivine index maps contain the mean index value for the individual TES pixels analyzed in the area covered by each bin. Valid olivine detections (based on analysis of individual TES spectra) generally have index values in the range of 1.015 to 1.060; however, some indices are more reliable than others (e.g., the Fo0-10 index also detects hematite) and these values may not be applicable in all cases. Note that binning may alter slightly the range of index values that represent valid detections. Users should read the description and discussion of these data in Koeppen and Hamilton (2008) prior to using these maps for scientific analysis.

Layer.Name: MOLA_Color_USGS
Layer.Title: MOLA Shaded Relief / Colorized Elevation, USGS
Layer.Abstract: This Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument colorized shaded relief data layer is derived from Planetary Data System source images at http://pds-geosciences.wustl.edu/missions/mgs/mola.html. This data product is a shape map of Mars at a resolution of 0.00781 (1/128) by 0.00781 degrees, based on altimetry data acquired by the Mars Global Surveyor MOLA instrument and accumulated over the course of the primary and extended mission. The MOLA Precision Experiment Data Records (PEDRs) are the source for this data set. The map is in the form of a binary table with one row for each 0.00781-degree latitude. Map coordinates use the IAU2000 reference system. The binned data include all MOLA nadir observations from the Mapping Phase through the Primary and Extended missions, from the end of aerobraking in February 1999 through June 2001. Additionally, off-nadir observations of the north pole are included from 87 N latitude and northward, taken during the spring of 1998, and of both poles taken during Mapping from 87 N and S to the poles. Data are adjusted using a first-order crossover solution for radial, along-track, and across-track position. Parts of orbits are excluded where solutions for these orbits are deemed to be poor. (Note: subtract 10000 from a MOLA mapping phase orbit number to determine the equivalent MGS Project orbit number.) Also excluded are shots more than 1.2 degree off-nadir (except as noted above), channel 4 returns, and any returns not classified as ground returns, e.g. clouds or noise, according to the SHOT_CLASSIFICATION_CODE. A total of nearly 600,000,000 observations are represented. Colorized TIFF source image provided by Trent Hare (USGS) 8/2010
